``` ini
[defaults]
collections_paths = :
```

In that case, the collection ends up getting installed into $PWD/ansible_collections/.
But I suspect that is a general issue with config types of 'pathspec' and not specific
to collection_path.
Yeah, this should probably be an error if the config has explicitly removed the paths...

comments.body:
This PR increases the complexity of `execute_list` a lot:

devel:
```
galaxy.py:958:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_list (complexity 13)
```

This PR:
```
galaxy.py:976:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_list (complexity 31)
```

I'd recommend breaking this method up into a method for each "type". As it is, I feel like it makes it difficult to review.
I agree, it's really bloated now. Now that I have it working, I'll simplify it.

I have replaced `execute_list()` with two separate methods and moved the nested methods to private class methods. Things are looking much better now.
```
galaxy.py:1035:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_role_list (complexity 9)
galaxy.py:1077:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_collection_list (complexity 9)
```

comments.body: Changing the default paths here is problematic because `collections_path` is also used by `execute_install`. We probably need to add these additional paths only in `execute_list_collection` and possible `execute_verify` if we want to be able to verify collections inside `site-packages` as well.

Update for those following the PR comments: After some discussion in slack: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/70147#issuecomment-646712442

So we do want it to apply to list and verify.  We want it to apply to install when install is checking whether things are already installed but do not want it to apply as a location that can be installed to.  We need to check the implementation to see if we can get away with setting the default here and letting the code sort it out or if we need to use a sentinel for the default and set it to AnsibleCollectionConfig.colection_paths as a default later in the code.

After today's meeting, the above is the long term plan.  But for 2.10, we're going to apply site-packages to list and verify but not install.

I've now looked at the code more closely and `-p`/`--collection-path` is implemented separately for install vs list and verify.  This PR changes the list and verify `--collection-path` but not the install `--collection-path` so it should be ready to go.

```
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ ansible-galaxy collection list community.crypto   
[WARNING]: You are running the development version of Ansible. You should only run Ansible from "devel" if you are
modifying the Ansible engine, or trying out features under development. This is a rapidly changing source of code
and can become unstable at any point.

# /home/badger/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ansible_collections
Collection       Version
---------------- -------
community.crypto 0.1.0  
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ ansible-galaxy collection verify community.crypto
[WARNING]: You are running the development version of Ansible. You should only run Ansible from "devel" if you are
modifying the Ansible engine, or trying out features under development. This is a rapidly changing source of code
and can become unstable at any point.
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ echo $?                           *[collection-list-site-packages]  (10:40:20)
0
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ ansible-galaxy collection install  community.crypto
[WARNING]: You are running the development version of Ansible. You should only run Ansible from "devel" if you are
modifying the Ansible engine, or trying out features under development. This is a rapidly changing source of code
and can become unstable at any point.
Starting galaxy collection install process
Process install dependency map
Starting collection install process
Installing 'community.crypto:0.1.0' to '/home/badger/.ansible/collections/ansible_collections/community/crypto'
```
I tested this out and it works as expected.

comments.body: Could anybody explain why this works/necessary? I think it deserves a code comment. It looks to me like it exploits some side-effect of changing the list in-place instead of reassigning the object but I don't get why this fixes the bug.

I believe it is due to mutating the `dirs` created by `os.walk`, which impacts future iterations that include that same `dirs` reference.

I'm sure we could refactor the code, to not require it, but this is a known good change that works.
After looking at the PR description, it sounds like it'd be saner to use a different variable name. Also, it looks like this could be moved closer to the loop that iterates over these dirs.
I think that's the point, it needs to mutate the existing reference, or the code needs refactored in a larger scale.

            for f in files:

comments.body: Wouldn't `ansible-galaxy role -v login` be an issue here? It seems like we should just be checking if `login` was set, or maybe displaying the error in `self.execute_login`.

No worse than it was before- it'll just show the usage dump in that case with an invalid ROLE_ACTION (as it did prior to this change), since the subparser seems to require that the subcommand be first. I just didn't want to create any future trip hazards by globally blacklisting `login` as an arg value without using the parser. I tried doing this as a hidden option first, but it doesn't seem that you can do hidden subparsers in argparse. :(

What if we were to keep the code here the same but move the error to `execute_login`. That way we are still relying on argparse to resolve the args like it does today and we don't have to complicate this already complicated bit of code.

comments.body:
@felixfontein could you check if making this
```suggestion
        version=collection.ver or '*',
```
would fix `list` in your env? It'd be great to know how to reproduce/debug this.

Yes, that actually fixes it. The collection printed there is `ansible.netcommon`, which is the latest git checkout from https://github.com/ansible-collections/ansible.netcommon

Maybe it's because it has an explicit `version: null` in its galaxy.yml: https://github.com/ansible-collections/ansible.netcommon/blob/main/galaxy.yml#L13. But when I comment `version: null` out, `ansible-galaxy collection list` simply will not work (both in `devel` and this branch):
```
ERROR! The collection galaxy.yml at '/path/to/ansible_collections/ansible/netcommon/galaxy.yml' is missing the following mandatory keys: version
```

> Maybe it's because it has an explicit `version: null` in its galaxy.yml

Oh, that would make sense. `dict.get('version', '*')` wouldn't fall back to `*` in case if the key exists but is `None`. Thanks for the pointer!
That should better be written as `dict.get('version') or '*'`.
Yeah, probably. I'm just trying to figure out on what level this should be fixed and if there are other cases where this problem would happen if I just patch here.

I attempted to fix this in https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/70185, but that ended up being way too invasive. Since `_display_collection()` is only used when listing collection information, I think it's fine to do `collection.get(ver) or '*'` here.
@samdoran it's already been fixed elsewhere to make sure that missing or falsy version is turned into `*` when the metadata is read.

comments.body:
If no collection paths are found, this will output an empty `{}` before the help and error message. This should be after the `raise AnsibleOptionsError` below.

```
> ANSIBLE_COLLECTIONS_PATH='' ansible-galaxy collection list --format json
{}
usage: ansible-galaxy [-h] [--version] [-v] TYPE ...

Perform various Role and Collection related operations.

positional arguments:
  TYPE
    collection   Manage an Ansible Galaxy collection.
    role         Manage an Ansible Galaxy role.

optional arguments:
  --version      show program's version number, config file location, configured module search path, module location, executable location and exit
  -h, --help     show this help message and exit
  -v, --verbose  verbose mode (-vvv for more, -vvvv to enable connection debugging)
ERROR! - None of the provided paths were usable. Please specify a valid path with --collections-path
```
Why? Doesn't it go to stdout while help goes to stderr? With typical piping, it'd be alright and the tools down the chain would be able to consume and empty "there's nothing installed" `{}`...
Awesome find. Fixed + added test.
The empty JSON object was being included in stdout along with the usage text. IMO this _was_ a bug / undesirable behavior.
I didn't know if it was intentional to output an empty dict. I don't think it will cause issues, just seems like it shouldn't be doing that.

Demonstration:

```
$ ANSIBLE_COLLECTIONS_PATH='' ansible-galaxy collection list --format yaml 2> /dev/null
{}
usage: ansible-galaxy [-h] [--version] [-v] TYPE ...

Perform various Role and Collection related operations.

positional arguments:
  TYPE
    collection   Manage an Ansible Galaxy collection.
    role         Manage an Ansible Galaxy role.

optional arguments:
  --version      show program's version number, config file location, configured module search path, module location, executable location and exit
  -h, --help     show this help message and exit
  -v, --verbose  verbose mode (-vvv for more, -vvvv to enable connection debugging)
```

Some options I can identify:

- Leave it as-is (patch w/ Sam's suggestion)
- We stop using `AnsibleOptionsError` here: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/649df97d9174a285bcb08b881c45d2af4058d450/lib/ansible/cli/galaxy.py#L1491
- Make `AnsibleOptionsError` send to stderr
- We change the conditional that throws the error to be `if not path_found and output_format != 'human'`.

The use of `AnsibleOptionsError` is to make in consistent with other sub commands. 

It looks like the help and `{}` will be it stdout. The error message is in `stderr`.
So the fact that the help is in the `stdout` could cause issues. If the help went to `stderr`, that would be better in this case, but I don't think we should change that.
Ok. Let's roll with it how it is now.
